swimming_creatures.name: Clownfish
swimming_creatures.description:
Clownfish, also known as Anemonefish, are famously
known for their bright orange colour and white stripes.
They are some of the few creatures able to survive the
stinging toxins of sea anemones, allowing them to form
a mutualistic symbiotic relationship with them. The
fish gains protection under the toxic tentacles, and in
return the fish can pick off parasites from the anemone.

swimming_creatures.name: Salmon
swimming_creatures.description:
Salmon are mid-level carnivorous fish, preying upon
small invertebrates and fish. They are well known for
their mouths that look like a bird's injured beak. They
start their lives in fresh water rivers and travel
downstream into the ocean, where they spend most of
their lives. Once they reach maturity they make a
dangerous journey back upstream to breed. Right after
mating they suddenly die for no apparent reason.

swimming_creatures.name: Mackerel
swimming_creatures.description:
Mackerel are small agile fish that are from the
Scombridae family, which also includes tuna and
bonito. Like tigers, they have a vertical stripe
pattern on their backs. Unlike tigers, however, they
are not fierce ambush predators, but instead feed
on small fish, crustaceans and plankton.

swimming_creatures.name: Moon Jellyfish
swimming_creatures.description:
Despite their name and appearance, moon jellyfish did
not come from the Moon. They are one of the most
common type of jellyfish, spanning all corners of the
world. They have many thin, short tentacles lining the
rim of their bodies that, thankfully, have no effect on
humans, along with a few larger arms stemming from
the middle.

swimming_creatures.name: Compass Jellyfish
swimming_creatures.description:
These living blobs of gel are a common type of
jellyfish, inhabiting shallower waters. The brown
streaks on its bell make it look like a compass,
hence the name. It is adviced not to touch the
tentacles, unless you think it is a good idea to
get a rather painful sting.

swimming_creatures.name: Lanternfish
swimming_creatures.description:
When sonar operators were testing the newly invented
sonar instruments during World War II they found, to
their surprise, what appeared to be a 'sea floor' that
was 300 - 500 meters deep at day and shallower at
night! It turned out that this false sea floor were
millions of deep sea fauna, most of which were
Lanternfish; small deep sea fish that have many
bioluminescent spots on their bodies.

swimming_creatures.name: Sabertooth Fish
swimming_creatures.description:
This nightmare of a fish is called a Sabertooth fish.
They have long, fierce looking teeth that resemble that
of the sabertoothed cats you see at the natural
history museum. Their eyes point upward to look for
prey silhouetted against the little light that
penetrates the water. Thankfully sabertooth fish are
too small for us to be on the menu.

swimming_creatures.name: Anglerfish
swimming_creatures.description:
What could be a more well known deep sea creature
that the Anglerfish. They use the light emitting
organ stemming from their heads to lure in small
fish from afar. The small fish, mesmerized by the
light, has no choice but to check it out. Eventually
the little fish comes across the angler fish,
inviting the little fish to take refuge in the
inside her mouth, safe from the cruelties of the
deep ocean.

swimming_creatures.name: Vampire Squid
swimming_creatures.description:
There are many things in this world that are named
based on their superficial appearance. The vampire
squid is a good example. It was named so because
of the reddish colour and the webbing between its
tentacles that resemble a bat's wings. Unlike their
name, however, they do not drink blood nor inspire
halloween costumes (although they do live in a place
of constant darkness). Instead they feed on the dead
matter and whatnot that trickles down from above.

swimming_creatures.name: Chimaera
swimming_creatures.description:
Not to be confused with the mythological lion with
a snake for a tail and a goat's head sticking out of
the back; a chimaera, also called a ghost shark, looks
like a cross between a shark and a stingray, with the
head of a rabbit. Chimaera are cartilaginous fish,
which means that their skeletons are made of the same
flexible stuff that make up our joints, just like
sharks and stingrays.

swimming_creatures.name: Cusk Eel
swimming_creatures.description:
This handsome gentlefish is a Cusk Eel. The deepest
specimen of fish discovered was a species of Cusk
Eel, called Abyssobrotula Galatheae. It reached a
depth of 8,730 meters (27,460 feet)! Also, Cusk Eels
are not actually true eels; They are just another
one of those things that are named after their
superficial appearance.

swimming_creatures.name: Dumbo Octopus
swimming_creatures.description:
Dumbo Octopi are the deepest living, and possibly the
cutest, octopi in the world. The octopi are yet
another creature named after their superficial
appearance. In this case they were named after dumbo,
a fictional elephant who had ear muscles strong enough
to provide aviation. The ear-like fins attached to its
mantle do indeed provide locomotive abilities.

sessile_creatures.name: Sea Anemone
sessile_creatures.description:
At first glance these may look like flowers you'd find
in the garden of someone who lives underwater, fearing
that some catastrophic event will wipe out all of
humanity on land, but they are infact animals. They use
their 'foot' to anchor onto a suitable surface. The
mouth that they have on the top is surrounded by a
mass of tentacles that they use to paralyze their prey
before drawing them into their mouths.

sessile_creatures.name: Barnacle
sessile_creatures.description:
It was long thought that barnacles were mollusks, since
they live in shells. It wasn't until 1830 that they were
discovered to be crustaceans! Yep, they are more
closely related to crabs than limpets and snails.
Barnacles start their lives as tiny free living larvae
that look unmistakingly like crustaceans. Later on they
attach themselves to a surface and form a shell.

sessile_creatures.name: Seagrass
sessile_creatures.description:
Plants are, without doubt, land creatures. After the
first plants grew on land they went crazy and covered
entire continents. All plants love land! Well, all but a
few. Some plants found out it was actually nicer to live
in the water for a change, just like the good ol' days.
Among these aquatic plants are the seagrasses.
Seagrasses are just like grasses, but underwater! They
photosynthesis underwater, spread underwater and get
eaten underwater.

sessile_creatures.name: Mussel
sessile_creatures.description:
Mussels are Bivalves, or two-shelled mollusks. They
cling on to rocks using a mass of thread-like material,
called a byssus, making them look like they have
beards. Mussels are generally colonial animals,
sometimes even taking over entire rocks. Unfortunately,
due to their sessile nature, they are unable to peform
physical exercise, and are thus unable to live up to
their name.

sessile_creatures.name: Reef Coral
sessile_creatures.description:
Corals are one those things that we tend to treat
as a background decoration, like what we do with
plants, which is funny given the fact that they are
animals, thousands of them infact. A coral is not
one, but many many individuals that make up a colony.
Each individual is called a polyp, and they look
like miniature anemones. Reef corals generally have
a calcium carbonate skeleton for structural support
and host symbiotic algae that can provide sugars.

sessile_creatures.name: Sponge
sessile_creatures.description:
If you asked me what the absolute wierdest animal I
know of is, I would definitely say sponges. They
have no body plan at all. They are just filter feeding
lumps of cells that can grow however, wherever,
whenever they want. You can cut up a sponge into a
million pieces and you'll get a million sponges.
Interestingly, one sponge was discovored to be able to
make burgers and even work at a fast food resturant.

sessile_creatures.name: Sea Pen
sessile_creatures.description:
Sea Pens are a type of soft coral that got their name
due to the resemblance to a classic writing quill.
Like all corals, sea pens are made up of many
individuals, called polyps, that make up one
superorganism. Unlike most other corals, however, the
polyps can take on different roles, such as feeding,
anchoring and reproduction. Luckily, Sea Pens don't
possess any writing capabilities, otherwise they would
have been hunted down for use as actual pens.

sessile_creatures.name: Bubblegum Coral
sessile_creatures.description:
When you think of carnivores bubblegum coral
definitely does not come to mind, but they are indeed
carnivorous. Due to the little sunlight they recieve
symbiotic algae would be uneffective. So instead
corals living this deep have turned to predation.
Each polyp will use their stinging tentacles to catch
any plankton that happen to find themselves in such an
unfortunate situation.

sessile_creatures.name: Tube Worm
sessile_creatures.description:
Not the sort of worms you would find in your everyday
garden. Tube Worms are deep sea worms that build
a tube for them to live in. They have no mouth or gut.
Instead they derive their nutrients from symbiotic
bacteria. By living near hydrothermal vents, the
bacteria can convert the chemicals from the vent into
usable nutrients. Tube Worms can also live for
hundreds of years.

sessile_creatures.name: Deep Sea Crinoid
sessile_creatures.description:
Crinoids are an amazingly unique animal. Crinoids in
shallower waters start off having stalks in their
juvenile stage, but as they grow the break free from
it and become a free living adult. Their deep water
relatives, on the other hand, are afraid of growing up
and remain stalked all their lives. They use their
feather-like structures to catch prey floating
through the water.
